subtitles.text: Good morning.

Leol's music originates from Matsumoto.

I enjoy creating artwork in general, including how to create a world view in a live performance.
As a musician, do you have roots in Mr. Matsumoto?
I think so. Matsumoto is one thing, but also the marching bands I met in Matsumoto, and the castle town's unique high-colored atmosphere.
I think that kind of glamour is at the root of my music.
Are there any songs inspired by Matsumoto?
When I was a child, I participated in the Matsumoto Bonbon festival with my parents.
It is a summer festival of the people of Matsumoto.
I think that song is one of the most danceable and upper-range Bon Odori songs in Japan,
The recently released song "Aokiya Karatsu" is inspired by Matsumoto Bonbon.
I took a look back at the lyrics of "Matsumoto Bonbon" in about 2021,
I was thinking about the major breakups and the eye-baggers, and how there is also the excitement of encounters,
The song expresses in depth in one sentence that life is also about parting while there is also the excitement of meeting,
I thought it was a very good lyric, singing about something universal.

When I first moved to Tokyo, I couldn't help but want to get out of the city.

For the final show of your first national tour in two years
I chose my hometown, Matsumoto, for the final show of the live tour.
